meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, well, welcome everybody. It's great to see you all. I'm really excited about this meeting. I think we have a fantastic group of people here. And I'm really looking forward to the discussion. So the way we're going to run this is we're going to go around and have everybody introduce themselves. And when you introduce yourself, please say your name, your institution, and then also, what is the grand challenge that you're most excited about tackling? And what is a crazy out-of-the-box idea that you have for tackling that grand challenge? And so we'll just go around and do that. And then after that, we'll have a more open discussion about some of the ideas that have been raised. And so I'll just start with myself. I'm Jeff Long. I'm at UC Berkeley. And the grand challenge that I'm most excited about is trying to figure out how to do carbon capture from the air. And a crazy idea that I have is to use metal-organic frameworks to do that. And so with that, I'll pass it on to George.
meeting_annotations.other: Jeffrey Long acts as the meeting facilitator, setting the agenda and structure for the introductions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: George Shields
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm George Shields. I'm at Furman University. And the grand challenge I'm most excited about is trying to understand the origin of life. And a crazy idea I have is that the first self-replicating molecules were not RNA or DNA, but were actually small peptides. And I'm trying to use computational chemistry to explore that idea.
meeting_annotations.other: A whiteboard with chemical diagrams is visible in his background.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great, thank you, George. That's fascinating. Okay, let's go to Pratik next.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Pratik Dholabhai
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, my name is Pratik Dholabhai. I'm from Rochester Institute of Technology. The grand challenge that I'm most interested in is developing new materials for energy applications, specifically for batteries. And a crazy idea is to use machine learning to predict the properties of new materials before we even synthesize them in the lab, so we can accelerate the discovery process.
meeting_annotations.other: A whiteboard filled with scientific equations and diagrams is visible behind him.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Leo Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hello everyone. My name is Leo Liu. I'm from Utah State University. The grand challenge I'm interested in is water purification, especially removing micropollutants from water. My crazy idea is to develop a smart membrane that can selectively remove specific pollutants from water, and we can control the selectivity of the membrane using an external stimulus like light or an electric field.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is using a virtual background of a desert landscape.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Very cool. Thank you, Leo. Okay, let's go to Burcu.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Burcu Gurkan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, I'm Burcu Gurkan from Case Western Reserve University. The grand challenge I'm excited about is also related to carbon capture, but specifically from industrial sources. My crazy idea is to use ionic liquids, which are salts that are liquid at room temperature, to capture CO2. And the really crazy part is to design the ionic liquids so that they can be regenerated using very little energy, maybe even using waste heat from the industrial process itself.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is very expressive and enthusiastic.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's a great idea. I love it. Okay, Wilson, you're up.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wilson Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hey everyone, I'm Wilson Smith. I'm at NREL and the University of Colorado. The grand challenge I'm interested in is artificial photosynthesis, so using sunlight to split water into hydrogen and oxygen. My crazy idea is to develop a system that's inspired by natural photosynthesis, but instead of using chlorophyll, we use quantum dots to capture the sunlight. And then we use enzymes to catalyze the water splitting reaction.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is using a virtual background of a snowy mountain range.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Wow, that's ambitious. I like it. Okay, Jenny.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jenny Yang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Jenny Yang. I'm at UC Irvine. The grand challenge I'm interested in is nitrogen fixation, so converting nitrogen from the air into ammonia. My crazy idea is to develop a catalyst that can do this reaction at room temperature and pressure, which would be a huge energy savings compared to the current industrial process. And I'm trying to do this using a molecular catalyst that's inspired by the nitrogenase enzyme.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Excellent. Thank you, Jenny. Okay, let's go to Will.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Will Bowman
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hey, I'm Will Bowman from UC Irvine. The grand challenge I'm interested in is understanding consciousness. And my crazy idea is to use quantum mechanics to try to explain it. So the idea is that the brain is a quantum computer, and that consciousness is an emergent property of the quantum computations that are happening in the brain. And I'm trying to develop a mathematical model of this.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker appears very thoughtful, often looking up and to the side while speaking.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, that's definitely out there. I love it. Okay, Jose.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jose Mendoza
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hello, I'm Jose Mendoza from Michigan State. The grand challenge I'm interested in is developing new methods for drug discovery. My crazy idea is to use artificial intelligence to design new drugs from scratch. So instead of screening existing compounds, we would use AI to generate new molecules that are specifically designed to bind to a particular target. And we could also use AI to predict the properties of these molecules, like their toxicity and their efficacy.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is using a virtual background filled with mathematical equations.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's really exciting. Thank you, Jose. Okay, Kristen.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Schell
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Kristen Schell from Carleton University. The grand challenge I'm interested in is developing new ways to store renewable energy. My crazy idea is to use a process called reverse electrodialysis to store energy in the form of a salinity gradient. So you would use renewable energy to create a concentrated salt solution, and then you could release that energy later by mixing the concentrated solution with a dilute solution.
meeting_annotations.other: The camera is positioned at a low angle, looking up at the speaker.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Very interesting. Thank you, Kristen. Okay, Matt.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Green
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hey, I'm Matt Green from ASU. The grand challenge I'm interested in is developing new ways to recycle plastics. My crazy idea is to use enzymes to break down plastics into their constituent monomers. And then we could use those monomers to make new plastics, which would create a truly circular economy for plastics.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: That would be amazing. Thank you, Matt. Okay, Peter.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Peter Reiners
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Peter Reiners from the University of Arizona. The grand challenge I'm interested in is understanding the long-term evolution of the Earth's climate. My crazy idea is to use the mineral record to reconstruct past climate conditions with much higher fidelity than we can currently do.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Long
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Thank you, Peter.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Feng Lin
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, I'm Feng Lin from Virginia Tech. The grand challenge I'm interested in is developing new catalysts for converting CO2 into useful chemicals. My crazy idea is to use a process called electrocatalysis to do this. So we would use electricity from renewable sources to drive the reaction. And the really crazy part is to develop a catalyst that can selectively produce a single product, which is very difficult to do.
